reviews.review_text: This is everything an action rpg sidescroller can offer! Fluid combat, gripping story and characters, nice music, good voice actors and a good gear system for upgrades and armor.  This is a game that I highly recommend to anyone. It's major selling point is actually it's combat that is so fluid, smooth and makes you feel like a total badass when chopping up your foes.  Worth mentioning is also that only one guy made this game (not counting voice actors and artists working on music) in only four years!

I'll be honest, I only bought this because the Humblr Store had it on sale and it was a pretty looking game with furries that took itself seriously instead of being a mascot title. That's a rarity, especially in the kind of mainstream stuff you buy on Steam or XBLA.  That was the reason I bought it at first, but I finally got around to playing and it wound up being the best $2.99 I ever spent and a game that might actually break the top 10 on my list of all time favorite games.  The first thing you'll notice going in is that the graphics are BEAUTAFUL and there's some real nice fine detail in the animations like the fabric of Dust's clothes rippling as he moves. The effects like explosions, projectale attacks, and lighting are also really pretty and can result in some great atmosphere and awesome moments during combat. It feels almost like an interactive cartoon at times.  It also ran maxed out flawlessly on my 750ti/FX-8320 at a solid 60FPS that only dropped to 51 during loading and cutscenes, but I think that's more an issue with how the game load assets than something that more horse-power or optimization is going to fix  The second thing is the story is great and will more than likely bring you close to tears on far more than one occasion, I can only describe the emotional rollercoaster than ensues from the ending of the second chapter onwards as something that wants to break you one way or the other. The story has some fantasy cliches, but it uses them well to paint a world that world that likable because it would be unashamably idealistic if it wasn't at war. I'd almost say it remained that way in spite of itself because all the drama and heartache makes it feel very much like you're earning a happy ending for all the people you help along the way.  The game also has a welcome sense of humor in it's lighter movemets that comes from hanging a lampshade on common RPG tropes like stuffing huge items in your pockets or random fetch-quests.   The gameplay is a simple side-scrolling RPG with Castlevania exploration and some pretty hefty rewards for putting the effort to cheack everywhere and uncover every secrect in the gameworld. The combat is very much a button-mashing that relies on timing and keeping up with on-screen action to rack-up combos and avoid getting hit instead of complicated combos or a huge arsenal of moves.   So yeah, I'd say this is worth a buy and a place in anyone's libraiy.

Dust: An Elysian Tail...  To be honest, I only bought the game due to the viusals on the previews. Those alone seemed to be amazing and played a decisive factor. At first, given all the reviews, I was a bit sceptycal. I was afraid that it would be an over hyped game by the community and in the end it would something bland. Fortunately, it wasnt the case.  So the big plus on Dust: + amazing visuals (except cut scenes - those appear to be from early free flash games) + cool combat system. Amazingly fluid! + cool soundtrack + interesting level construction + Easy to play and to master  + gameplay length just right  The bad: - Story is rather generic (it has a couple of twists, but nothing unseen before or trully unpredictable) - may become repetitive at times - can´t seem to skip some cut-scenes. - perhaps a 'nightmare' mode should be considered  I think those minus can even be neglected / forgotten given the quality of the game. I can imagine myself playing it over again in a couple of years time.  I had fun playing this game. I took my time to make my character quite strong (I think I was level 50 - 52 when I finished the game. I had a lot of fun in some levels, and loved the final boss battle. I have finished the game, recovered my last save, gained a couple of levels only to play the final boss battle again.  I thought that the game could be a bit more difficult. Appart from a couple of situations that were actually tricky, you can almost go through the whole game without actually feeling that you are in an eminent risk of dying. However, this is a dream game at every level for a younger audiance.  My recommendation - get the game and play it. You will often find it on steam sales w 75% discount (I have seen it like that 3 or 4 times until decided that I should buy it), but after playing it, I feel that the full price would be a fair deal.  Hope the analysis was useful for all the undecided.  Cheers, Latinnus

'Dust: An Elysian Tail'   is a Metroidvania style platforming action-RPG in which you play as the protagonist, Dust, accomponied by sidekick Fidget on a mission to save Falana and it's inhabitants from General Gauis' wrath. The game was almost entirely made by Dean Dodrill (the creator) alone. He handpainted the games' visulals and vistas, wrote the story alongside Alex Kain and programmed the game himself.  I played the game on the normal difficulty setting using a keyboard and a mouse and spent about 16 hours completing all the levels and collecting all the collectibles. I made short notes about what I felt was positive and negative about the game. The following are the positives and negatives of my experience of the game.    Positives:

When I get to play a good game the least I can do is tells others about it. And this is a good game. It comes with a well written story (but not too deep) taking place in a great set of scenery with adequate variety. The screenshots on the store can give you an idea of what's included. What I loved most is the simplicity of the controls which you can get the hang of quickly so you can enjoy playing the game fluently. For treasure hunters and completionists there are things to look for with the appropriate rewards, that do tend to make the game easier though. If you are looking for a hard game then you should not start on normal difficulty.

I wish Steam had an 'Ehhhh...' option.  Let's start with the good -  Dust  looks great, controls well, has a passable soundtrack, and the writing can be quite funny at times. I laughed often at the deuteragonist Fidget's lines, and while she was entirely grating at first introduction by the middle of the game I only found her likeable.  Unfortunately, main man Dust himself never improved much. He goes back and forth between being some edgy amnesiac dude to bland to a bleeding heart. He doesn't improve in motivation or reasoning, even after his exposition scenes. The villain meanwhile twirls his mustache at every turn while literally slaughtering men, women, and children alike. Fun.  This game never really marketed itself more than a simple beat-em-up, but the mechanics here are beyond simple. You have essentially four attacks - a ground clear, a ground slam, an air knock-up, and some attack where you spin through the air. Fidget also has the ability to shoot projectiles which are amplified by your spin attack, but there's very little difference between the 3 options and they don't interact with your other attacks in any way besides juggling enemies.   This wouldn't be a problem if the game was varied in other ways... but it's not. Enemies are basically all reskins of each other and the best way to play is button mashing due to the number of mobs that can clutter your screen. The game has a parry mechanic, but outside of it happening randomly the only times you bother to make use of it are for enemies designed to require its use. In fact, none of the attacks in your repertoire feel particularly natural to use - they all seem as effective as one another and there's no combo system to speak of. There is  some  degree of animation canceling utilized via crouching, but again it's pointless to use given how  Dust  requires absolutely zero strategy or mechanics to speak of.  Level design is passable at best and at worst makes you want to tear your hair out. Levels are simply too long for what they offer. Like the gameplay, they're repetitive and on the rare occasion things are mixed up, it's in an annoying fashion. I have absolutely zero idea why anyone would think that hazards that essentially explode randomly would be a good idea, much less to cover entire sections of levels with them. And surround them with spike traps. I certainly love having three hazards explode at once, leaving no opportunity to dodge, only to send me into conveniently placed spikes so that I may die without option. Fun.  Anyway, regardless of all these multiple faults I did, I suppose, have some fun with  Dust . Despite the terrible story, the repetitive gameplay, and the occasionally annoying level design, the game did offer some honestly cool moments. The animations and sprite effects when dealing with a group of enemies can look amazing, and stuff like grabbing a guy with your sword then slamming him into a group of enemies takes a long time to get old.  With that, I'd recommend  Dust  to the younger gamer. It's something I would have loved at a young age, where flashy effects and simple gameplay were the bee's knees, but for anyone else I'd probably pass.

The gameplay works really well, and the fact it was programmed by a single person is simply impressive.  The story is enjoyable and quite well-written. The character are likeable. Despite the quite serious tone, there's a lot of humour and even some references to other games (like that stupid tornado thing from Castlevania 2). The game is a little short, but if you're a completionist and want to clear everything, it might take about 15-20 hours, otherwise... about 10. This game was recommended to me, and I now recommend it to you.

This is a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and delivers it in style. A straightforward, side-scrolling platformer with simple button-mashing combo-style hack n' slash combat, pretty graphics, and a relatively interesting storyline. It's got a very stereotypical anime-esque appearance, but there's beauty in the simplicity of the game. It's extremely well developed, easy to pick up and play, and nicely eyecatching. The animation is wonderfully smooth, with very subtle background effects, and a wide variety of environments to move through as you open up more of the wider map.   I tend to think of this game as being a bit simple, but it's a work of art and it's hard to believe that it was entirely the product of one person. It must have been a labour of love, and that effort shows through. Dust is an interesting character and, almost despite myself, I became engrossed in his story and the way in which it unfolded. I was expecting something very basic and repetitive as this is a 2D platformer I bought during the sale, mainly because I'm a sucker for pretty artwork in games. I didn't expect much beyond a couple of hours of simple gameplay and levelling up a few times before polishing off a boss and ending the game all in time for tea.   A week later, after running through the game twice (I upped the difficulty level the second time around) and earning all of the achievements, proved me totally wrong. At first I was skeptical; I found the characters to be a little bit twee and stereotypical, but as they and the story line developed I got hooked. It's suitable for all ages so don't expect any gore or adult themes, but there's a certain appeal in the innocence of the game; it's certainly not boring, and there are enough challenges and changes to keep you interested despite the fairly repetitive nature of platform gaming. It may appear cartoonish but there are some serious moral themes discussed and life lessons to be learnt. Picking up new abilities throughout the game gets you returning to previous maps to complete things you couldn't do earlier in the game, which nicely prevents it from being a linear run-through from one level to the next.   It's hard to criticise this game because it doesn't promise any more than it delivers. You don't feel short-changed by the simplicity of the game play or the slightly 'cutesy' characters. It's easy to play through, which might be disappointing if you're looking for more of a challenge. It is fairly repetitive but the enemies do get tougher as the game develops, matching your character's development. The challenge arenas are the only places where you can really push your skills to try to get that elusive four-star rating.   The other downside is the boss fights - it's a button-masher so just keep hitting the combos for long enough and the boss goes down, it's as simple as that. But again, it's hard to criticise because the game delivers exactly what it promises. It's enjoyable but not astonishing. I recommend it as a pleasant and pretty game to play, a nice bit of simple escapism that isn't going to challenge or frustrate you.

Dust: An Elysian Tail   really exceeded my expectations. It has been a while since I've seen a game, made in the twenty-first century, that's heavily story-driven. I honestly expected this game to be much more cliche as I was expecting Dust's sidekick, Fidget, to be annoying and Ginger to be the FRI ( f orced  r omantic  i nterest). Fortunately I was wrong as Fidget was actually a pretty charming character and Ginger, despite sharing some obvious chemistry with Dust, doesn't pull the whole  'falling in love, saying 'I love you,' and share a long kiss'  sort of thing with Dust. The other characters in the story are also pretty memorable, the voice acting is well done, the soundtrack is great, the visual style is superbly beautiful, and the story keeps you drawn in and intrigued.  As for the gameplay, it has a fair amount of RPG elements (despite only using one weapon throughout the game), fluid combat, and vivid and vast environments. The game is also pretty nostalgic in a sense as it's a 2-D side-scroller. The game honestly isn't too long in terms of the main quest, but there are plenty of side quests and things to unlock and find to keep the game going especially if you're the kind of person who's a  'completion freak.'   Now there are some people who negatively judge the game because it supposedly has sort of a  'furry'  vibe to it, but don't let that deter you. Honestly, I'm by all means not a furry and I personally can't stand a majority of the fandom. But trust me, this game is a lot more than meets the eye. The game has zero traces of the perversion most people typically think of when it comes to the furry fandom. For me, the fact that the world in this game, known as Falana, is populated by anthropomorphic animals just makes it seem a lot more unique and stylized.  For my final verdict, I give  Dust: An Elysian Tail  a  9/10 . Whether you consider yourself a furry or not, this game is an intriguing experience that keeps you drawn in and it has its own unique lore. This is a game that I can consider myself to be a fan of and if there is to be a sequel.... I'm definitely excited to see what will happen next!

The story keeps you interested and you will want to know what will happen next, who is everybody and why things are happening. There are some references from other games (some are very well hidden) but not too hard to find if you use your head.   Some negative points worth noting:  I used xbox 360 controller to play and sometimes found that using analog stick to perform certain actions might cause you to do the wrong move. This is really annoying when you try to do trials where time and precision is crucial. I failed so many times when my character jumped instead of ducking and sliding or vice versa. I do however recommend playing with a controller even though keyboard and mouse works great, controller is still better.  You will probably want to play it once because once you know the story there will be no point in playing again so if you played on casual you are simply wasted your time because it was too easy and you can finish it in few hours. There are, however, 25 sidequestes which you can complete and you won't get all achievements unless you do them all.  Difficulty curve is not ideal. On harcode mode is really hard to start that will cause you to die over and over until you reach some levels or keep killing same enemies over and over. Later on it when you level up and get some items it becomes too easy. Simply be patient and you will enjoy the game without any annoying issues.  Overall it is great game that is worth your time. Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the few games I completed entirely, multiple times. I love this game for many reasons: the music is absolutely amazing, the background and characters are beautifully rendered and react to wind, rain and fighting, the combat has about 6-7 combos in total but you have so much freedom of movement that it feels like your pulling off 15-20 string combos, and the story is amazingly compelling. The sidekick you have through the game, Fidget The Nimbat, made me laugh many times and is a really good asset in combat. The combat rewards you for having long unbroken combo chains (there is an sidequest that has you get a 1000 hit combo) and reminds me of something Platinum Games would make.   There are many little nods and easter eggs in the game from all of gaming history. They can be usuable items to the merchant to treasures you find in the world. The game really rewards exploration with items and money and health upgrades.  The one weakness Dust: An Elysian Tail suffers from is the boss battles. It is usually one enemy that you fight , and it becomes trivial because you dodge their attacks and chain combos on them when there just standing there. The boss battles can be overlooked if you get really interested in the story.  I would reccommend you play this game of the 'Tough' difficulty, because normal is too easy for most people. The 'Hardcore' difficulty is best saved for a second playthrough because you take more damage and enemies take less damage.  I cannot reccommend this game enough to anyone that calls themselves a gamer. If you can get over the fact that the characters are anthromorphic animals and it is metroidvania styled , you will see a compelling story, beautiful design, music that is on par with Super Mario Galaxy, and a combat system that allows you to chain combos indefinitely.

This game is both figuratively and literally a work of art. The beautiful music, painstakingly detailed environments, and passionate voice acting blew me away. Then Fidget and all 304% of her adorable-osity sealed the deal. At first the story didn't really spark much interest--being the typical 'all powerful mysterious warrior with amnesia traversing the land helping it's people while trying to regain his dark and mysterious memory'-- but as it went on it started to pull me in. It's best described as a cross between Okami and Rayman Origins with a little bit of Kingdom Hearts sprinkled on top. (Pros and cons below.)  Pros: -Beautifully orchestrated music -Painfully detailed environments and weather effects -Very touching and emotionally impacting. Feelings of pain, sorrow, love--concepts of life and death are handled maturely like they should be and conveyed to the player -Excellent, passionate voice acting -Exciting and tense moments  Neutral: -The humor is 50-50. There are some funny jokes. There are some dry jokes. -Storyline may or may not provide the player with much interest. -The difficulty fluxuates. Some areas are very easy, some areas suddenly ♥♥♥♥ you.  Cons: -A bit on the short side -Typical hack'n slash with redundant combat -VERY few combos to use; especially for a hack n'slash -Hordes of respawning enemies can be a bit overwhelming and annoying at times -Boss battles are complete jokes. Normal enemies are more life threatening than the bosses -Practically no replay value  Conclusion: -6.5/10. While the gameplay and hack'n slash elements are regretably limited, this game is a work of art. It's a 2D game that has infinitely more heart and soul put into it than most overrated 3D Micheal Bay games out today. It is TRULY a work of art and deserves as much support and recognition as it can get for its BEAUTY instead of gameplay which unfortunately is below par. Of course artistry isn't for everyone. This game is not for everyone. But that doesn't stop it from being truly beautiful.

You will often find, among gamers and critics alike, diverse opinions that state the positives and negatives of various games, with things such as 'the game is good' or 'the game was too short' or 'the controls suck.'  This is not the case with Dust: An Elysian Tail. I have been a gamer my entire life, ostracized as a child in school by the very people now addicted to Call of Duties and Madden NFLs. I have watched the evolution of gaming from the 8-and-16-bit era of Mario and Sonic, the evolution of PC gaming from text based RPGs to DragonAge and Skyrim.  Of all the games I have played, from casual Runescape to the intensely cerebral Europa Universalis, from the flashy twitch gaming of Smash Brothers to the thought-out fights of Guild Wars. 'Dust: An Elysian Tail' is by far one of the most defining creations in the Gaming Industry. What makes it more spectacular and amazing is the story of a single man hand-drawing and developing the game from scratch over years, of an indie developer given a chance on Xbox Arcade.  Dead Dodrill has brought to us a game that, in collaboration with secondary writer Alex Kain, and composers Alexander Brandon and HypderDuck Soundworks, defines everything we love about gaming. He brings us back to the core elements of a video game.  I can say, without a doubt in my mind, that Dust: An Elysian Tail is, by far, the greatest representation of Video Games as an Artform. If there ever any confusion or concern if games could be consider Art, Dead Dodrill has proved us otherwise.  No amount of praise I could give would satisfy my love for this game. For 17 years, Blizzard Entertainment's Starcraft franchise has held a special place in my heart as my favorite game of all time. Upon completion of this artistic masterwork, I can say that this has changed.  Dean Dodrill, Alexander Brandon, and everyone else that not only made this game possible, but brought it to the attention of the general public. I thank you, and I heartily reccommend this game for anyone.

After beating Chapter 1 (hardcore mode) review   So far, so good. And I mean  really  good. The story, admittedly, has been done before (Ex-superevilarmy soldier suddenly can't remember things because reasons and is now good guy but slowly uncovers his dark past and has to reconcile with his sins etc etc), but it isn't presented or executed (at least so far) in an incredible cliched or dull manner. It's clear that Dust, the main protagonist and player character, actually did some pretty evil stuff and assisted in the annihilation of a race (or maybe only partially). When you figure out more about Dust, you start to become wary of learning about his past, afraid of what you might uncover and realize who you are playing as. Gameplay is solid, hack-and-slash type deal with mobs of enemies coming at you once. I immediately went to hardcore mode starting out, and personally I feel like a lot of the difficulty does come simply from damage outputs from enemies being increased. I can be dancing around everyone, sawing through flocks of those flying toad dudes with dust storm, and suddenly git rekt if I get hit like once or twice (ie the insta-kill giants, but considering they're giants that makes sense). This isn't to say the enemy AI aren't smart in their own right, definitely not a bunch of bumbling idiots with aim-bot and ridiculous stats (*cough*modernfps*cough*), but it does effect my experience enough to be noted. The combos, tho,  the combos . I swear I feel like a Touhou character whizzing around and throwing everyone and everything into the air and then showering the battlefield with bullets from Fidget and making Storm from the X-Men look like a South Dakota summer breaze on a Sunday in July. I am rewarded executing a long chain of combos and moves and what nots with extra experience rather than just spamming a basic or other attack. In fact, you can't even spam a single attack or any single set of attacks, because you'll git rekt. The mechanics of each move or dust storm or Fidget's bullets force you to change things up as you go along because even these super-amazing-I'm-a-♥♥♥♥ing-god move sets have their limits, even hurting yourself in some casese if not executed properly. Skill is needed to cut through literal armies of monster mooks. Speaking of the enemies, the design is repititive but at the same time varied. In the first chapter, you'll see the same monsters from the beginning continuously re-appear throughout to the end, while others are still added as you go along. However, very rarely did I see more than two of the same looking hairless-club-wielding-dog-thing, each enemy type has several skins to change around and add some color to what would otherwise be a boring homogeneous legion. Even futher, the basic design and look of each enemy is pleasant to look at in itself. They're colorful and full of little details that give the mooks some character of their own. I even found myself feeling a little sorry for them, wondering if they had hopes and dreams of their own, but I guess that's just my traumatization from Undertale talking. The final boss of chapter one definitely threw the plot for a loop. At first I thought 'oh no super cliche warlord guy rallying usually non-threatening army of mountain monsters into a full-fledged and organized assault where HAVEN'T I seen this before', which is still technically true even after defeating him and listening to his dialogue. But  holy ♥♥♥♥  did I feel like a god damn prick when his backstory was revealed and suddenly things are going from happy-go-lucky fantasty monster slaying to 'oh my god what am I doing I'm a monster'. Something that did definitely irk me after the boss fight however was the fact that you still go about slaying the monsters, which Fidget even speaks up about wondering if they should continue slaughtering them. Voice acting is a  little  cringy at times, and that's nothing from the actual voices but from the lines themselves, tho I am an anti-social prick that rarely has a decent face-to-face conversation in real life so I probably wouldn't know. However I will not lie in saying anyone can tell the budget wasn't exactly sky-high when listening. The friendly characters are nice to chat with, that's for certain. No one's overly annoying or obviously a rip-off of some other character from another game to serve the same purpose. I really like the travelling merchant guy and his mysterious appearance, can't tell what sort of anthropomorphic animal he is. However I distinctly remember wanting to close off every conversation with the merchent in Aurora village as quickly as possible. Finally, a comment on the anthropomorphism. At first glance of this game I thought the only reason it had an overwhelmingly positive response was because only furries were looking at it and only praising it because anthro (which I would like to say really quickly that I don't give a rat's ♥♥♥ if you're a furry, I just call out circle-jerking when I see it). However I was slapped across the face with wrong when I realize it's more of a Disney-esque anthro thing going on, rather than just 'because anthro'. The designs of the characters are cartoony and simple, I can tell only just enough time was spent on them to be aesthetically pleasing and not overly elaborate with human-animal mixture stuff. That being said, I'm still carving my way through chapter 2, and will post my review for that probably maybe idk. Thanks for reading.

At first glance I had a lot of assumptions about what this game would be, not anything to do with story or characters, but the type of genre the game inhabits and how it goes about that. In many ways it met those assumptions and while I was right it still managed to exceed my thoughts.  A few screens and videos and to me this came off as a simplified metroid-like with a more straight forward beat-em up presentation. And my deep abiding love for any exploration based game was left mildly wanting to know that it really has more in line with Odin Sphere/Muramasa than Metroid it still has enough exploratory quirks to ever so slightly scratch that itch.  What brings this simplicity bright, to me, is the trappings that are around the basic structure. The combat is fine to me, I don't find it completely compelling but it is satisfying in the way your character feels powerful and the agency through which you give him that power is what compels me through the game. Items, leveling up, quests. The depth is not great but it's all deep enough to just make the rest of it so easy to breeze through and feel constantly in a state of needing to get more from the game because it has the ability to give you more. I feel this lust for progress on the mechanical/statistical spectrum that drives me through the game itself elegantly.  And that's not to say the story is creating any sort of roadblock to that. It's actually very well put together and while nearly cloying and childish at times it has an aspect that reflects back this younger version of yourself. Old Saturday morning cartoons, Disney movies, or even just any broadly aimed animated feature. It plays into that in a way that almost makes it okay to be so silly or ardent in child-like way. It's also interesting in how juxtaposed that is to the darker aspects of the story and how easily it accomplishes that without feeling overbearing or too self-serious. And it's startling how good the voice acting is in this game, disregarding some odd lines that sound re-recorded and not quite on point as the same voice from the same session.  The gameplay itself may not be memorable to me but it really is fun to play and progress through. It may feel a little simplistic to start or jarringly sharp or oppressive in its presentation but I think its just so out of our usual context for that type of over the top character expression that it feels wrong at first, though over time it felt right at home.

Dust is a serious adventure RPG that can be turned way simple for easy fun / exploration, or way hard into true hardcore 2D bash-em combat with an impressive combo system that can do various types of attacks, from ground to slide to jump and much fancier aerial moves.   The plot is relatively simple. You are Dust. You woke up in a field, not knowing yourself, when a sword... yes, a flying and TALKING sword floated up to you and addressed you as Master. Then Fidget, a Nimbat, showed up and wil accompany you on whatever quest you are supposed to go on since she comes with the sword. As you head toward the village in the distance hoping for answers, you hear fighting... Some sort of monsters are attacking the town, and you leapt into action...   The graphics are quite good, sort of Disney-esque type animal humanoid that looks far cuter than it should for all its seriousness, about finding one's true self and all the war and attack and civilian casualties, and good vs. evil and all that.   Sound is also quite good. There's some debate whether the protagonist voice sounds a bit too young, but sounds okay to me. (And you have to play the game to see why.)  There are basically three attacks (later there's a fourth, the ground slide/kick) blade, dust storm, and Fidget burst. It is the combination that makes things deadly. Blade plus jump is an aerial attack. Blade plus jump plus dust storm yields an aerial super attack. Dust storm and Fidget burst creates attack swarm. As you level up each ability through EXP (via quests and kills) you'll gain additional attacks and combos. (On casual difficulty this is done automatically)  You will also encounter various types of equipment: armor, amulet, left ring, right ring, and 'augment' (weapon enhancement). You will often encounter blueprints to build more advanced equipment... provided you find the blacksmith and have enough materials. Some stuff are available at merchant.   There are many sidequests in the story as you encounter more NPCs. Some will ask you to find X ingredients, while others want you to retrieve something or someone, or reach a particualr area and search for something. Doing them yields extra EXP to level you up.   Other activities that yields EXP are just talking to every NPC you come across (but you only get that once).   There are special 'treasure chests' in the world for you to find, and most involve some sort of a puzzle. Usually it is to pull a 'bombfruit' toward an alloy gate to blast it open, but the bombfruit can be at a challenging place so it can be difficult to pull it properly esp. when the bomb fruit may come with a timer (after X seconds, kaboom!) There are also special 'friend chests' (12 of them in the world) for you to find as you unlock your 'friends' captured in the cages. It's another type of collectible, but a fun one.   As you learn new skills, such as floor slide (to get through narrow low tunnels), double jump ( to reach extra high places), iron grip (to climb the vines) , you will discover new areas you haven't been able to reach before, and often that is how you find these extra treasure chests and cages. So exploration is a must. You will be told percentage of areas you missed and/or treasure you missed, so don't fret.   The game autosaves when you pass through a 'save point' (temple) which also heals you. You can also trigger a manual save on a savepoint. The savepoint also serves as a teleport point that allows you to leave the map region, if you bought some teleport gems (not that expensive, and you did get a few for free).   The game never felt too frustrating, except the problem of opening up a certain area before you are ready. For example, there's a mission where you need to find a girl in the 'Hidden Cove', except you can't explore that area unless you have Iron Grip skill, which is only available at the end of Sorrow Meadows. The game doesn't always make this clear. There are also some quests that are a bit too whimsical, or even on casual, way too difficult without advanced skills like double jump. However, if you are the type that goes for every bit of completion, you will no doubt feel frustrated now and then, even on casual.   There are also six 'trials', sort of a 'speed-run' through a certain level where you try to take as little damage as possible, while fighting your way past monsters and environmental hazards. And they award high level equipment, depending on how well you do, with rating of up to 4 stars (depending on score).   All in all, Dust is a very good game that, IMHO, looks way too cute for its own good that people will have problems taking ti seriously. If you can get past it, you will find a rewarding action-adventure with good puzzles and challenging bash-em on higher difficulty levels.

First off, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD GET THIS GAME NOW.  Dust is a game made entirely by a single person (save the voice acting and music) over 4 years. It's pretty much the best PC port of a game to boot!  The game plays out sort of like a sidescrolling beat-em-up with light RPG (leveling and item progression) and Metroidvania elements (a few powers which give access to different areas). The controls are tight and responsive, making it easy to pull off combos.  The characters are anthropomorphic animals, but definitely do not be turned off by it; don't let the 'furry' stereotype drive you away from this fantastic game. The environments ooze color and creativity, and I usually found myself marveling at the art style. The story isn't revolutionary, but it's solid and well-done, paced well throughout the game.  There are also a few references to other games, the main one being Fidget. Much like Navi from Legend of Zelda, Fidget is a small flying helper throughout the game (A nimbat, actually), providing mostly comic relief. Although some people find her voice and behavior annoying, I found it cute and endearing.  My only complaint would be that the difficulty throughout the game isn't very challenging unless you turn it up to max. You can master most of the swordplay about mid-game and be fine.  Overall, this game is probably the best thing I've played in a while; it's a hell of a blast to play, and I always found myself kept going throughout. Buy it whenever you can, a steal at $15, robbery when on sale.

Replaying this game on the ps4 made me realise that i should write a review for this game, not because it needs it but because i want to pay my respect to the person that made it, because this game was largely made by a single guy over the course of 4 years.   -The gameplay-  This game is a sidescrolling Beat's em all with some light metroidvania and rpg elements which mean you will learn new moves throughout the game, those moves will allow you not only to fight enemies but also to reach places that you could not reach before.  The controls are responsive and fast, this makes for very fast paced combats with combos reaching sometimes the thousand of hits. It does, however, feel a little bit repetitive like most games of the same genre, the game would have benefited from a little bit more combos.  Sadly the game is also too easy on Normal difficulty, i died only once on the second boss, i would recommend you play on hard from the get-go if you are an affecionado of the genre.  That being said the gameplay is solid, fun and works well for the 13-14ish hours it takes to finish it(20-21 if you complete everything.)   -The presentation-  Dust AET is visually stunning, featuring some of the most beautiful 2D i've ever seen in any games, the animations are also really impressives, fluid and detailed.  The design may not be for everyone with it's anthropomorphic cast of characters but i found them quite charming and it did not bother me in the slightest.  The story is nothing groundbreaking but has the merit of being interesting and fun to follow with some strong moments here and there thanks to the duo of Fidget and Dust.  The music is really good and has a few memorable themes which is quite rare nowaday in video games.  I will also point out that the voice acting is very well done but only available in english.   -Overall- If you don't mind the repetiveness inherent to the genre then you will find here an amazing game that is well worth the 17$ full price.

I'm mixed on this game. It has a lot of problems that, by rights, should mean it isn't fun. But I've still logged over 30 hours over two playthroughs, so something about it works...  There are three really big problems with this game in my opinion. First, the balancing is very, very poor. The first couple hours of the game are, by far and away, the most difficult. This is because your first few levelups, which take a long time to get, multiply your base stats more than tenfold, but enemies are balanced for your stats once you've leveled up a bit, so they are wildly overpowered to start with. You just cannot afford to get hit more than a few times at the beginning of the game, but you can shrug off small mistakes for the rest of the game, even during the final chapter.  Second, the fighting mechanic is shallow. The core of the game is fighting mobs of enemies, but all of the enemies have very similar attack patterns, and your moveset isn't very complex either. After a while, you get into a grove of comboing enemies using the same spacing tecniques, and all of the fights feel very similar to each other.  And third, in my opinion, the story isn't as good as it could have been. Avoiding spoilers, when Dust's identity is revealed, the story has a lot of opportunity to explore subtle themes and to paint the antagonists in a somewhat sympathetic light. Instead, in my interpretation, it doubles down on making Dust a designated hero who gets to kill the Bad Guys because he's the Good Guy.  For those flaws, though, the game is still a lot of fun to play. There's a lot of exploration in the game with plenty of very rewarding secrets hidden in each level. And the art is absolutely geogeous. Playing this game is fun, but there are other games I can play that are both fun and don't feel like they have rough edges.

Play Length: From what I understand, I got about one halfway the game. This is all I feel like playing. Given that I didn't finish the game, please take this review with a grain of salt.  Positives: There are some things to like about this game. The combat is actually pretty good. Many of the moves have a satisfying feeling to them, and you can tell that a lot of love went into designing this aspect of the game. The background art is also quite lovely, and the main character looks quite good (when viewed from afar!) I also like that there's a nice amount of challenge on hard mode.  Negatives: As I said, the art is quite nice when viewed from afar. Unfortunately, this game has many cutscenes which plaster large character portraits all over the screen. And these portraits are terribly drawn, and hideously colored. The amateurish nature of this art really detracts from the overall presentation of the game. The story also has the same problem... the writing feels straight out of a Saturday morning cartoon, complete with obnoxious side-kicks and cringeworthy jokes.  But hey, you can skip the cutscenes. A bad story shouldn't hold a game back too much. And I was doing precisely that, but I still found that I wasn't enjoying the game much. Another problem is the in-game soundtrack. Let's talk about why the original Metroid is such a great game... one reason is the fantastic soundtrack which is simulteneously memorable and atmospheric. It not only creates a perfect mood, but by being memorable, it bonds with every area you explore, giving that area it's own identity. Dust: An Elysian Tail doesn't know how to do this. The music in every area sounds generic and boring. It lacks flavor, it lacks atmosphere, it is never memorable, and it never lends any of the areas a sense of identity. Therefore, every area you explore in Dust feels the same. They look different, but they feel exactly like the last area with a new paint job. Bad Metroid-likes have a tendency to make you feel like you're just going through the motions, dilligently filling out your mini-map without really enjoying yourself. Unfortunately this is one of those games.  The rather good combat isn't enough to counter-balance this. The most essential element of a Metroid-like is to make exploration feel fun and exciting. Dust fails to do so.  Overall: I like the combat. I like the general in-game look. But I don't like the music, or the story, or the feel of the game. I don't think the game does anything to elevate itself over the glut of so many indie Metroid-likes. I would not call this game 'bad,' but I would certainly call it mediocre. Some people may really like this game... if the story and artwork appeals to you, then I can certainly understand why you might enjoy it more than me. But I honestly feel that few people would call this a particularly special or interesting Metroid-like.  About my rating system: I have two things I rate on. Overall score, and soundtrack. Personally, I feel like game soundtracks are tremendously undervalued; to me, it's a vital factor in getting me into the game. For the score, I grade on a scale of 1-10, and I try to grade in such a way that each number has a meaning and equal importance. The meaning of each number are as follows:  0: Garbage, 1: Awful, 2: Poor, 3: Underwhelming, 4: Mediocre, 5: Decent, 6: Good, 7: Great, 8: Excellent, 9: Phenomenal, 10: Masterpiece  Dust: An Elysian Tail's score:  Game Rating: 4 (Mediocre) Soundtrack Rating: 3 (Underwhelming)

Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the most beautiful games I've ever played. But can the art make the game? Let's find out.  This game is a hack 'n' slash / platformer that ultimately fails at both. The main problem with this game is that everything is oversimplified. The platforming has absolutely no difficulty, as the jumps are enormous.   As for the combat, you have like 3 or 4 different 'combos'. Considering that 90% of the game you will be fighting hordes of enemies, this becomes a major flaw. You will repeat the same attacks over and over and over. And after a certain point, it's not funny anymore. It could have been saved if at least there was some variety among the enemies. However, while having lots of awesome models for them, they all have pretty similar mechanics. Most of the time, you just need to attack them straightforward. There's no tactics at all. There are not different approachs, not even when fighting bosses.  Another point where the game fails is at progression. There's no sense of advance at all. You get some 'world skills', like crawling through small tunnels or double jump, but they do not bring anything new; no challenge, no variation. When killing bosses you also get some 'combat skills' that in the end are all the same area attack.   The story is a big meh. Generic for the most of it, just with a small twist near the end, but not enough to save it. The voice acting is overall good. As I said before, the best part of the game is the art. The graphics are ♥♥♥♥in' amazing and unique, and the main characters feel integrated in the environment (the enemies not so much). This is far beyond what a normal indie game achieves, but it's done at the expenses of all the other aspects of the game.   But overall, I don't consider the game can be saved. It lacks so much meaningful content. The main story lasts about eight hours, but I would have prefered it lasted half the hours and had something to fill them.

DeviantART and FurAffinity got together to produce the single most unsatisfying metroidvania ever made, and like both those communities the quality of this game largely depends on which part you happen to be looking at at the time. This goes for everything from the art assets to the music to the animation and writing (but never the plot, the plot is consistently terrible).   A good first example is your main character(s), Dust and Fidget. They're fairly well drawn (most of the time), and while they aren't the most original characters (brooding amnesiac warrior, blue, and comedic animal sidekick, orange) you actually enjoy moving them around the screen! Their animations are fluid, and Fidget's body shifts to fly against things like a strong wind or to keep up with you when you're moving fast. You can tell that a lot of work was put into them, which is why I have to wonder why so much work was put into making them as hard to see as possible. You'll be fighting in pitch-dark caverns, or raging blizzards, or with the camera zoomed all the way out, the random weather effects have a preference for torrential downpours every fifteen seconds, and with all this on top of the tons of enemies and various weapon and attack effects (theirs and yours) it's a wonder the game runs half as well as it does with as much as there is on screen. The level shown in the fourth screenshot on the store page is probably the worst offender, because in addition to the ugliest enemies in the game it introduced scads of allies  and  everything is either exploding or on fire,  and  some of the enemies are   invisible copies of yourself (invisible enemies not shown)  .   There are more problems than not being able to see the good animations, and those include being able to see the bad. You can't tell from the still image, but the deer in the first screenshot on the store page move like something from Scribblenauts or South Park; they don't seem to move their knees and you can see where the legs on the rig meet the body and it's such a jarring transition from the seamless little bunnies from just a screen earlier. Likewise, the town guards in Vaguely Asiatic Villiage are a jerky collection of bodyparts brought into unlife by Flash and commanded to randomly bend over and pick up invisible objects, the end result a bit like a marionette being controlled by a butterfingered puppeteer. By far, though, the worst offenders are the soldiers and spaceships of the volcano level. Just look at the fourth screenshot on the store page, and look how jarring that CG-rendered spaceship looks compared to the hand-drawn enemies and environments from every other screenshot. Now imagine that in motion! It's something straight out of A Valley Without Wind, and I can't understand what would lead them to add such a thing. There's no lead up to CG-rendered space ships, there are no indicators that CG-rendered space ships will be making an appearance, and there's nothing you can do about it.   The phrase 'there's nothing you can do about it' actually segues into my biggest complaint, the empty feeling this game's plot leaves you with. Despite the bright colors, lush backgrounds, and (occasionally) cute furry characters, Elysia or Falana or whatever Not-Asia is called is a dark, depressing world. Everything you do is met with failure as part of the game's theme of 'even when you do everything right, you can't fight fate'. And while I can understand the creator was in a bad place when he made this game, it creates a sort of dissonance in the tone of the game when you have genuinely laugh-out-loud banter alongside a furry analogue for the holocaust. When I remember the scenes with Dust and Fidget poking fun at each other or breaking the fourth wall, or even taking some beautifully-aimed jabs at other indie games, it hurts, because they took characters we actually cared about, the  only two  characters we cared about, ran them through the grimmest, darkest plot they could find, and still expected us to care, even when the plot didn't make any sense, even when the plot never made any sense. By the end of the game, when you're met with another failure in a string of horrible failures, you're not even relieved it's over because you still have so many darn questions! Why were any of the events in the game occuring? Why did anyone, at any point in time, think that any of your actions mattered? Why did anyone tell you they mattered? They didn't, and the game drives it on home every other step of the way that they didn't, except for side quests which somehow matter within the confines of the sidequest, and are coincidentally where all the game's good dialogue, and its heart, lie.    Why were there spaceships?

Dust is, in a word, amazing. Simply outstanding. It has been a long time since I've played such a remarkable platformer. It caters to every aspect of what makes up a good game. The visuals are sharp and beautiful, complemented by the grand, fantastical soundtrack, which both work in tandem to create these big, lush environments that perfectly match the tone of the well-crafted story. It's a classic tale, to be sure, but it still succeeds in taking the familiar and making it unique, clever, and memorable. The cast is colorful and lively, resulting in natural interactions that really help to establish the world around the characters. The humor is genuine and witty, the intense moments are properly gripping, and the two never clash. Every event has its time in the spotlight and gets its due attention. And when the climactic parts take the stage, they truly steal the show. It was at these highs that I felt the most astounded.   But, of course, there's the gameplay. The wonderful, flowing, visceral mechanics that really complete this epic. The eponymous hero, Dust, controls like the warrior you've always dreamed of. He's agile, acrobatic, and swings his sword with ferocity and grace. The controls are intuitive, combat always feels rich and rewarding, and I never felt a cheap death or a fight unfair. If anything, the fiends in this world never stood a chance. There's nothing more satisfying than cutting through hordes of enemies, launching them to the heavens, and sending them into oblivion with the combined power of sword and sorcery. You really feel the gravity of every power, ability, and upgrade you get, and it's great to backtrack and rediscover new places in secrets in old maps. And even better when you're clever enough to discover them early! The game never lets you down or leaves you bored, or wanting more than it can deliver. It's fun, challenging, and cinematic. Dust is worth every cent and second invested in this epic tale.

There are a few decision points that might affect the story, but don't seem to; even those are rare enough to be surprising when they come up.  Combat is simple, even repetitive, once you get the hang of it, and the world is small enough to explore fully, after gaining a few movement abilities. Mashing buttons works well enough to entertain a child, and the story progresses quickly enough to entertain adults. Save points are frequent, and most supplies are plentiful with the shopkeeper's help, so there's little danger of actually losing.  The nods to other games can feel a bit out of place at times, but all work within the framework of Dust's skill set, and are amusing when you understand the reference. They're also out of the way, though you'll probably run across most of them while looking for something else.  So, is this game for kids, or for adults? For novice gamers, or for the indie in-crowd? Perhaps both, for each question. I wouldn't recommend it for hard-core gamers who value gameplay far beyond storyline, but for the rest of us, it's a fun way to spend a few evenings.

*Heavy Sigh*   Let me first start by saying this Gem started off as a 'It's on sale so why not?' purchase that has dramatically changed my view of 2D Sidescrollers forever.   Artwork: 10 / 10   The bread & butter for the majority of players. This game is gorgeous to behold at any given point of the journey. The Hand painted textures simply turn this adventure into that storybook adventure you always dreamt about. The forest are full of life thanks to animated backgrounds & a bright color pallet. Even the dreaded marshes and volcanic regions of the world feel vivid and full of personality thinks to these details.   Gameplay 10 / 10   Silky Smooth & Flashy! Words cannot describe the swordplay in this one. The majority of your attacks seem infused with the spirit of the wind and the visuals reflect this. The screen fills with various distortions and mirror images of your lighting fast slashes that seem to cut away at the air itself.   The puzzles of the game mostly involve destroying barriers with hovering bomb fruit that follow you due to your signature move DUST (IE they follow the wind you create). Their are small jumping puzzles over spike pits or lava at times as well. It is never enough to frustrate the player so fear not!  As you may have read the game plays out on a 2D stage, but thanks to multiple paths it feels deep and the areas meaningful as you journey threw them.   Story 9/10   Many have claimed the story to be cliche and a bit predictable; I did not see this in the least bit. The plot moved along nicely and kept me guessing along the way. While I was somewhat close at guessing the Antagonist true identity and background information, I was never spot on.  Play for the story, stay for THE CUT SCENES!!!!  The cut scenes MAKE this game in my honest opinion; dialogue between you, your blade Ahrah and your companion Fidget ensures you talk to everyone to hear what your companions have to add to the conversation. The cut scenes are presented beautifully by focusing on the speaker at the time, giving you that 'storybook' feeling as you converse your way threw the world.   Characters 9/10   I know I know how can I rank the cast of a game I've only seen for 10-ish hours against the likes of hero's like commander Shepard or Link? Easily, threw solid voice acting & a superb personality! Dust (Main Character) plays the part well of someone trying to find who he is or what he needs to be doing considering waking up with no memory of who or what he was before he woke up in the forest grove.   His companion Fidget (Think Navi 10.0 Except Useful / Cute / & Slightly OP ) provides the comic relief threw out your journey. You WILL talk to everyone just to hear what she has to add to the conversation I promise you that =).  Even your sword Ahrah has a few memorable lines threw out the game. The rest of the NPCs scattered threw out the land are a joy to talk to, each with their own personality and colors so things never get dull.   Music 9/10   You will love the soundtrack. Its upbeat when it needs to be for the boss battles and fits in well with whatever your environment is. I've even downloaded the soundtrack because their are a few songs that either move you or leave you with fond memories. I've no complaints at all in this department.   To Summarize I'm giving this one an oddly rounded up 10/10!    For the sale price I got it for (5.00$ ish) I can think of nothing better. I've never been one to enjoy side scrollers but this one changed all that for me. Thanks to the solid voice acting, the charming characters, aw inspiring artwork & flashy game play I've never been happier*  *Possible Spoilers About Ending: You Have Been Warned =3 *    As a final note I thought about not recommending this one at all...  It was one of the only games among thousands that I had played that when I finished I had to spend the ENTIRE night reading fan fiction about alternative endings because I was crushed with how things ended up. I was that emotionally attached to the characters & that in love with the world around me.     They say sometimes that life is about the journey and not your destination; I believe that and without a doubt I wished this story had never ended....  Ashes to Ashes my Friends,  Onxius

This is going to be a longer than usual review than I usually do, but I'll summarize this game now before I dig into that: Acceptable. General: My biggest complaint about this game is that it falls under 'You get what you pay for', much like Earth Defense Force, Shoot Many Robots, and other cheap knockoff games. Story: Now, Dust has a lot riding behind it. This is perhaps root of most of the game's problems plot-wise, because a lot of the lore in the game is barely touched. It also ends with a questionable cliff hanger, again bringing up more questions behind it. As far as the actual story is concerned, it's paced up until a given point and hinted on deeply until you reach said point - Inwhich vague, general background details are (optionally) given to the player. The story is average here, certainly not bad. The dubbing in many cases, as well as character expressions, isn't as pleasing as one would expect - Though it is /slightly/ bareable. Gameplay: Takes some getting used to, the combat system is easy to master. In fact, it's easily abused - Especially on normal difficulty. This game combines platforming and combat, but is more focused as a fast-paced side-scrolling beat-em-up. There exists stage hazards which also must be avoided. The leveling system is also very generous, but balanced so that one get too far ahead too early. Overall: The game scores a 8/10. I have a second issue with this game: It's way too damn easy if played with a sharp mind. I should not be killing the final boss 3 times over only to get hit by him 5 times. When you posses attacks which can deal 1,500 damage per tick on a boss with 60,000, and it area of effect is that of pretty much the whole screen, I can't help but feel my breif back-and-forth sidequesting may have been a bit excessive towards the game's progression - An issue which falls in alignment with my first, this is expected.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a fantastic mix of action adventure and Metroidvania with beautiful graphics, a good story and okay voice-acting. Also fun to play.  + Beautiful character, level and combat art; organic looks + Okay voice-acting + Good story + Metroidvania + Fading out overlay where obfuscating avatar except for really important stuff 0 Dynamic zoom sometimes make battle harder than necessary - No Inn (100% hp) - Scenes need multi-skips because animation cannot be skipped - No restart for challenges! - Digital analogue stick, either no movement or full speed - Auto-equipping food to quick-use slot; vanishing items/loot; automatic item-consumption - Slipping of edges after jumps  Hint: There is are two decision-based achievements. In order to get them manually save before entering Ivydale Glen or on the first save point you encounter there.  I was immediately enamoured with the game when only a minute or so into the gameplay breaking a wall gave me an insight into the developers humour   by providing me with the 'mysterious wall chicken'  . When seeing others play the game I was already impressed with the game's design but doubted gameplay would be tight and fun. Fortunately my doubts proved baseless.  Controls are basically very tight and fluid except for one major flaw and a few more or less seldom occurring situations. Overall playing with a controller is pretty much the same as playing with keyboard and mouse, i.e. one didn't feel better than the other. The major controls thing is that movement speed is controlled digitally as opposed to analogue, i.e. when using a controller and moving with the analogue stick the avatar is either not moving or moving full speed (which is also not very fast). When platforming you need to stand for some time on a platform in order to be able to jump from it, i.e. having one platform above another and to its side you cannot swiftly jump from the lower platform to the close edge of the higher platform and, changing direction, jump again right away - that will always be considered a drop. Blocking is an essential part of combat and you are told you need to face the enemy but it's not always possible to change the character's direction in time. Furthermore, it seems the enemy also has to face you. There are some bigger enemies that may be distracted and attack away from you thus backhanding you without the chance to block. The character will gain a dash ability which allows for quick evasive manoeuvres. Unfortunately, this cannot effectively be used to pursue an enemy which drew back since immediately following with an attack will have the avatar automatically attack in the direction opposing the dash direction as opposed to attacking in the direction the player indicates with the analogue stick. A few times battle was made harder than necessary when graphical foreground elements obfuscated avatar and enemies or when the dynamic zoom goes in so far that the tells for incoming attacks cannot be seen, the latter being a problem with the final boss.  I demand total control over use of items so I feel somewhat angry at the game for effectively not letting me disable consumables. You can deselect the current consumable but as soon as you collect another it will automatically be assigned to the quick-use slot. Additionally, the game automatically uses Revival Stones when dying and automatically gives away crafting supplies when that can advance a current quest. In theory, I'd like to save up Revival Stones for boss fights but since the game has some enemies being able to one-shot you the stones are often wasted on underlings. With enemies like that I deemed consumables useless and never healed except for testing at the beginning of the game, the occasional bump of controller against my desk and save points that heal up to a certain percentage of total HP (depending on your difficulty level). Later on, you will receive equipment with regenerative attributes. The game indicates when it deems the avatar close to death which is basically nice but irritating over longer periods, read the whole beginning of the games. That's why I think the threshold for 'is dying' should always be lower than what the save points heal you to. I feel like changing regions in the game should fill up your HP or there should be some kind of Inn that lets you sleep and heal up.  I like games that let you skip sequences. This game has that to a degree. You can skip dialogue but only dialogue. You still have to wait through any intro, outro or intermediate animation. This also may require you to skip more than one dialogue per sequence. When dying in quick succession I felt like the death animation was sort of celebrated too much and I wanted to be able to just skip to loading. Somewhat related, the challenges could use a reset button bringing you back to the start of the challenge for when you know you can't achieve the wanted ranking in the current run.  Some more minor bickering: Sometimes loot gets stuck inside walls even rewards from destroying static objects. I don't see a reason loot should ever vanish as long as you don't leave the 'room', i.e. the area shown as one location in the minimap. Here, loot is gone after something like 10 or 15 seconds. I think it adds to the flow of the game that loot jumps around a bit. Then again, I was aggravated by loot often jumping over my head. And why doesn't Dust Storm simply collect loot instead of randomly flipping it around? The player cannot leave a room if enemies are close, that's okay. However it's not okay that enemies can leave the players attack range by leaving the edge of the room. Why would you have more than one blueprint of anything or be able to sell more than one? It seems blueprints are acting as high-value loot which doesn't really compute.  Some more praise: If for some reason the avatar is where HUD elements go the HUD becomes see-through except for essential information like low HP - very well done. Again, design feels like it has received some love. Regions have different designs and apart from where you expect otherwise, i.e. with built-up structures, the levels look very organic, i.e. they do not feel lazily pieced together from some palette. And there are atmospheric elements that show effort over simply making a playable game, e.g. wild life or footsteps in the snow. The Ugly pendant is a really nice fix. It allows to get that one achievement even in late game. Thanks for that.  Dust: An Elysian Tail is one more very easily recommendable game, even if you are already somewhat tired of platformers.

I'm going to open up this review by being straight up honest: I'm not a big platform game fan. I don't hate them, but they really aren't my favorite genre. This is why it's taken me so long to get around to playing Dust. That being said, Dust has two major pluses going for it over other platformers for me. One is that the actual platforming elements are fairly simple and straightforward, and even the 'tricky' portions are not the type to be super frustrating. The other is that it is a Metroidvania type game, which I am much more tolerant of anyway.  To be blunt, this game is really good. It has a generally good pacing, with some minor but not game-ruining exceptions, and on top of that the story is actually engaging and interesting, which is an unusual thing for any platforming game I've played before. The combat is fast-paced without being overwhelming, and the difficulty is easily adjusted to the player's level of skill, though hardcore action gamers may find the game a little easy for them. It is one of those games you look forward to playing when you get home, eager to see what the next level or revelation brings, and it's a breath of fresh air amongst the first person shooter crowd. While hardly the only side-scroller these days, it's a testament to how high-quality indie games can be.  This isn't to say it's perfect. The game's RPG elements, while interesting, are not particularly deep. The crafting system requires either a lot of grinding to utilize fully, or can be ignored entirely, which means that it either needs work or should be removed entirely. Finally, some of the sidequests require some real snooping around even above and beyond what is expected, making them a little frustrating.  On the whole, these complaints are exceedingly minor though. It boils down to this being a very fun game worth 15-20 hours, and at the current price it's a steal.

In the gaming climate as of late, two things are regarded as near constants. The first is that indie games have small development teams, while the second is that any game which has a longer-than-usual development cycle never turns out to live up to expectations (we're looking at you, Timeshift and Duke Nukem Forever).  Dust: An Elysian Tail basically takes the cake on both counts.  With the exception of the voice acting and the music design, everything in Dust: AET was done by a single person. Dean Dodrill took the artwork, animation, coding, storyline and even the creation of a PC version he deemed worthy of release and spent nearly half a decade getting the job done.  And it definitely shows, but not how you'd expect. Dust: AET is, indie job or no, one of the most well-polished and complete 2D MetroidVania-style games to grace the PC. To find something 'better' for our trusty desktops/laptops, you technically have to break the law and go trawling for roms.  While the anthropomorphic/'furry' aesthetic may be something of a turn-off for some, the artistic style of the characters in this game is like the sprite-based graphics of Terraria, a choice made by the developer (and the singular is actually correct in this instance) and nothing more. Having just beaten the game on Normal difficulty, I can say that Dust is a very strong entry into the Metroidvania genre. The game wisely borrows elements that worked in both Metroid and Castlevania while retaining its own identity, with plenty of small but substantial additions to the formula, such as quests, crafting elements, and new movement abilities. The most significant change is to the combat system, which takes more of a spectacle-fighter approach that encourages you to string together large combos without being hit.  The game's visual style is truly striking, with lush colors and highly-detailed environments. While the animated cutscenes aren't quite on the same level, the actual in-game animation is quite good. The voice-acting and music are fairly well done, if ultimately a little unmemorable.  Dust isn't without its faults, to be sure. For a completionist like me, the Normal difficulty started off reasonably challenging, but gradually dropped in the face of high levels and the best items. The story can also be a little hit-or-miss at times. Finally, a couple of the puzzles are also a little obnoxious, partly because the unusual flight ability sometimes seems like the solution when it isn't, and one puzzle where the in-game hint is almost no help at all (I ultimately had to look it up).  Still, I had a lot of fun with Dust - it comes highly recommend to any Metroidvania or platformer fans.

8/10 First I'll cover the good things. The combat flows very nicely, is fast paced, and very cathartic, but not too easy as to be a meaningless obstacle. Levelling up feels good with that little bit of knockback the character takes, and since each 'skill gem' gives your character a sizeable increase in power. The crafting system is easy to handle and the shop system works well to provide you with health items and crafting materials. My favorite part of the game is the art. The environments are colorful and distinct, and the animation is superb. The things I have mentioned constitute the majority of the game experience, so if you want a fast-paced, beautifully drawn metroidvania, it's all there.  Now the bad things. There is too much dialogue. It helps advance the story and give it a deeper plot with good characters and a motive to do what you're doing, but I don't think that much dialogue fits in such a fast-paced game. In the levels you dash from room to room, monster to monster, just hacking your way through everything, and suddenly you encounter an NPC who eats up at least 5 minutes of your time. Now the solution wouldn't be to reduce the dialogue because that would weaken the world and the story. It would be better to slow the pace of the game just a little bit. You are able to dispose of most monsters without putting too much effort into it and once you get the hang of it you just fly around the screen dicing up monsters like a salad. If there were more variety in how you take down monsters, like those spectres that are only vulnerable to spell damage, working through levels would be at a better pace. In order not to slow down backtracking, you could reduce the overall number of monsters. So, even though the time it takes to clear a stage may be about the same, the pace is different. The abilities you get as the game progresses are neither creative nor game-changing once you get them. Each spell is immediately better than the last, so the lightning is just better than the fire or 'baseballs' as I've come to call the first spell. The movement abilities like the double-jump only serve the purpose of allowing you to progress. The best abilities are gained towards the beginning. Some people don't like the bosses, but I thought they were fine. The similar size to you gives it more of a 'duel' feel rather than a 'underdog' feel.  Even after all that, I still think it's a good game. The dialogue is even remedied a little by the ability to skip dialogue scenes, even though you miss some plot. First playthrough with completing some sidequests and doing a bit of backtracking to find treasures is about 10 hours for me.

Ok I don't usually do reveiws of games I've played..... but this game is somthing that has really raised the bar on my expectaions from both adventure and beat'em up games. You play as Dust in an Anthropomorphic world(Animal people). He awakes not knowing where or who he is. Then you are greeted and named by a floating talking sword called Arah. The sword's pint sized gaurdian Fidget shows up next. After a short exchange you sent off on an adventure.  Pro's:  1.This game has a very well executed combat system that results in Dust flying across the screen throwing out blows, casting magic spell, and using the Duststorm to rack up combo's and cause massive destruction to anything on screen. 2. Exploring never feels like a chore and you are ecouraged to come back to area's you have been through before to reach new areas to get loot and face challenge dungeons as you gain new abilities. 3. The RPG elements put into the game allow you to specialize Dust skills, but it will restrict you a bit only allowing a one skill to get so high allowing your others to catch up. Here is what I mean. The game has four base stats Attack,HP,Defense,and Fidget(magic/duststorm). Your have reached level five and you have put all your skill points into Attack. The skill tree will not allow you put a fifth point into atack until your other skills have all been brought up by one. This kind of system is put in so the player doesn't suffer from a handicap farther along in the game when enemy's are tougher. 4. The story will keep you engaged and the world that is it's setting is beautiful. Which bring me to my next point. 5.The entire game, except for a few enemies and your sword, is hand drawn. This type of graphical choice in a game is always refreshing and is something that many Triple A title's never do. (exept the current Rayman game) Con's: 1. I had very few problems with this game. One thing I wish would have been better is the map. It needed to be a little more detailed. A few labels here and there wouldn't hurt and the terrain should have been displayed. They didin't need to save space to prevent the game file from being too large. This could have been inpimented. 2. Sometime with all the crazyness going on on screen you can somtimes lose track of yourself in a mass of enemys. It doesn't happen often but it could result in you taking a hit ending your combo and loseing extra EXP. There is no way to fix that your character is already brightly colored. It's not much of a problem but it is there.  Verdict. This game is a good 12 hrs long if you play it how it is meant to be played. Doing a few side quest and exploring. This game is must play. 95/100.
